Title: Simon K King opens up about reducing around 25kg weight during the lockdown
Content:
FacebookTwitterPintrest

Looks like music composer Simon K King remained muted on social media platforms during the lockdown to come out with something surprising for his fans and well-wishers. No, this time, it isn‚Äôt a music track of the composer that has grabbed the attention of the netizens, but a collage of two of his photos ‚Äî before and after lockdown looks. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve reduced around 25kg since the start of the lockdown and I am still reducing,‚Äù he says, adding, ‚ÄúBut this is the weirdest thing for me to talk about. If it‚Äôs about music, I can talk on and on. Talking about losing weight is quite new to me.‚ÄùBut prod him slightly, and he talks gushingly about his body transformation. ‚ÄúIn February this year, I weighed around 128kg. I never bothered about it. But during the lockdown, I decided to set small goals in terms of reducing weight. I started intending to reduce 3kg to 5kg during the first phase of the lockdown. Then, I aimed at reducing another 5kg in the next phase and so on. That was how it worked.‚ÄùSimon points out two changes in his lifestyle that has helped him ‚Äî eating at home and eating on time. ‚ÄúMany musicians like me tend to eat outside food a lot. Thanks to all the food-delivery apps, we get food at the click of a button. Eating at odd times was a big problem. After finishing recording at midnight, I would order whatever I would get at that time. And then, sleep till 11 in the morning and again, have brunch. But during the lockdown, I was able to get rid of that habit and deleted all the food-delivery apps from my phone. During the lockdown, I started eating home-cooked food on time. When my eating habits changed, I started seeing the results. That pushed me to do more workouts. I have always been physically active ‚Äî playing badminton and swimming, but that didn‚Äôt have any effect on my bodyweight because of my eating habits,‚Äù he shares.Talking about the initial spark that motivated him to reduce weight, he says, ‚ÄúMy wife has been telling me to reduce weight for a long time and then, there‚Äôs my trainer Ramnath. He has been after me for almost two to three years. During the lockdown, he gave me high-intensity workouts daily, which I am continuing. He planned a workout routine, which I could do at home ‚Äîburpees, jumping jacks, skipping, etc. The workouts not only helped me reduce weight, but also strengthened my body.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Simon reiterates, he believes in body positivity and losing weight shouldn‚Äôt stress one out. ‚ÄúLosing or even gaining weight is a health criterion. Sadly, I have come across even kids being bullied for being slightly hefty. The focus need not be on how you look, instead, it should be on health. Set small goals; when you achieve that, you‚Äôll get inspired to do more. Had I set a goal to reduce 10kg at one go, I would have lost interest halfway,‚Äù says Simon as we wind up the conversation.

Title: Women cops on Bullets feel empowered and are much-appreciated
Content: Women police officers going around on Bullets on Covid-19 surveillance duties in Thrissur were making such an impact, ever since the lockdown began in March, that DGP Loknath Behara recently announced their service would be rolled out across the State.The 12 women cops on the team, named Daredevil Riders, are happy to be pioneers. Sharing their experiences with us, they say, ‚ÄúNot only does it help us reach those in quarantine anywhere easily, it also boosts our confidence.‚ÄùThrissur City Women‚Äôs Police Station SI Sindhu P V, the leader of the team, says Thrissur City Police Commissioner R Adithya had floated the idea of bike ops not only to better aid women, but also to empower the officers and others in the process. ‚ÄúWe started the training in February and were planning to start the service soon, and that‚Äôs when the Covid-19 pandemic struck. Then, it was decided that our service can be used for Corona surveillance,‚Äù she says.The team, who can be contacted on emergency number 1091, has four bullets, with two officers travelling together on duty. While women cops have to take a two-wheeler licence as part of police training, most of them were new to Bullets, Sindhu says. ‚ÄúBut we picked it up in a few days,‚Äù she says. Helping women who get stranded in the lockdown situations, checking on those in quarantine, reaching help to people living in areas that can‚Äôt be accessed on cars or jeeps, taking awareness classes, helping people access grocery services‚Ä¶ they do it all.And the Daredevil Riders have heartwarming and LOL experiences to recount. One officer, Bindu T C, says, ‚ÄúMany in quarantine say, ‚ÄòOnly you care about us now, nobody else wants to come this way.‚Äô There have also been instances when people tip us off when people break quarantine protocols. The reverberating sound of our Bullets has now become familiar even in interior areas, and as soon as people see us, they ensure that social distancing, masks are in place.‚Äù Another officer, Sindhu A N, says, ‚ÄúMost people are very cooperative. There are even those who randomly bring us tea upon spotting us on duty. And they say kind words on how it‚Äôs a noble service.‚ÄùThe service has emboldened the officers as well, they claim. Jina N V, one of the riders, says, ‚ÄúI was using a scooter before I became part of this group, but not anymore. Riding such a vehicle gives a sense of confidence and seeing people waving at us while riding for duty, inspires us to give our best.‚Äù Sindhu P V narrates a funny incident that makes all of them burst into laughter. ‚ÄúOnce, we were riding into a very rural area and needed directions. So we stopped at a spot, where quite a few people were standing around. But as soon as we alighted from the Bullets, everyone sprang to their feet, ran and locked themselves in houses and shops! We had to find our own way ahead,‚Äù she says with a chuckle.

Title: Neha Gowda: I am not scared, but I am being careful on set
Content: Kannada television 's popular face Neha Gowda , is back on set, albeit for a Tamil serial, Roja , in which she is doing a cameo . In a quick chat with us she talks about her new show, returning to set during the pandemic and more.During the lockdown, I realised just how much I love acting and how badly I wanted to get back to work. I used to tell myself that I was not missing work and not getting bored at home, but on the first day of work on June 23, I woke up at midnight and was waiting to start the shoot.I am doing a guest role on a Tamil serial called Roja, in which my character Nisha appears for about 10-15 episodes. The character is important to the plot and the story. The interesting bit is that it is as good as working on a Kannada serial set, as I am sharing screen space with Vinaya Prasad, Ravi Bhat, Trivikram and Veena Sundar. The serial will be aired after the lockdown is lifted in Chennai.Since the cast includes actors from both Bengaluru and Hyderabad, and the director is from Chennai, once everyone reached Bengaluru, they had to isolate themselves for a few days and follow standard protocols. Even on set, all precautionary steps were in place. Everyone is checked thoroughly and then sent in. Technicians and actors wear masks and we sanitise our hands every five minutes. Given that the pandemic situation is getting worse by the day, we need to follow all precautionary measures laid out by the government and just be positive. I wouldn't say that I am scared, but I am doing my bit to stay safe, like carrying my own cutlery, water bottle and other stuff that I would need in a day.

Title: Vasuki Vaibhav: Law is not a routine legal drama: Raghu Samarth
Content: Rekha is one veteran actress in Bollywood who shares a great bond with the younger generation of actors. She is especially close to a few of them and that includes Aishwarya Rai Bachchan.

Title: I cannot think of making a film without Anant sir: Hemanth M Rao
Content: Earlier this year, the Godhi Banna Sadharana Mykattu team announced their next project, Sapta Sagaradaache Yello ‚Äì a romantic film that was slated to take off sometime in June or July. The pandemic, though, derailed all those plans. "Thankfully I was still only scripting Sapta Sagaradaache Yello when we announced it. The lockdown gave me time to work on it," says director Hemanth M Rao , as we got talking to him over a video chat about the film and more.The title has a literary reference. Tell us more...The title is very apt to my central theme. It was suggested to me by my co-director Gundu Shetty. I usually struggle with titles; it is the last thing I think of. When I was talking to him, he suggested a Gopalakrishna Adiga poem, which was apparently written after he lost his dog. And if one reads the poem carefully, the lines are actually very beautiful. The words struck a chord with me, which led me to take it as the title..The poster launched on leading man Rakshit Shetty ‚Äôs birthday has been a talking point, with people deconstructing it. You'd shared some interpretations too... I like the idea of teasing audiences with slight hints; they are intelligent and I need to treat accordingly. I usually consider them more intelligent than I am. So, I wanted to give them that and I liked the idea of this poster because there are many details. There is the character's name, the IPC section under which he is booked, a wallet with a girl's photograph, the money he has, what clothes he is wearing and stuff. It was like a snippet into his background for the story. So, what is clear is that Rakshit plays Manu, he is in prison for a crime and there's a girl's photo in the wallet.Given that it is a romance, people are curious about the female lead.I haven't got to that yet. I usually research a lot for any film and wanted to visit a couple of jails and talk to certain people to understand things better for my story. But because of the current climate, I've not been able to do any of that. So, a major portion of the story is a blank in my head, as I'm yet to understand that world better. Once I see that better, I'll know who would be apt to cast.Will this film be your hat-trick collaboration with Anant Nag For me, it is impossible to think of making a film without Anant sir. But I know I have to offer him a role that is worthy of him. There is something, but right now, I can neither deny nor confirm this.Tell us about Tenali and the reasons for its delay...Tenali is a period film and it happens around the time India gets independence. It is a big canvas. We cannot think of doing that right away. There are various reasons for this. Rakshit has an equally big film in Punyakoti . I will need time to work on a film of this magnitude. So, we will start it after Punyakoti.

Title: Dhanush prays for Amitabh Bachchan‚Äôs speedy recovery from COVID-19
Content: On Saturday night, news of Bollywood legend Amitabh Bachchan getting admitted to a hospital in Mumbai started doing the rounds. Soon, the actor himself took to Twitter to write that he has been tested positive for COVID-19 , and requested those who had been in contact with him in the past few days to get themselves tested. Soon, his timeline was filled with tweets from his fans and well-wishers, praying for his health and wishing him a speedy recovery. Among those who reached out to the legendary actor was his Shamitabh co-star Dhanush Amitabh tweeted, ‚ÄúT 3590 -I have tested CoviD positive .. shifted to Hospital .. hospital informing authorities .. family and staff undergone tests , results awaited .. All that have been in close proximity to me in the last 10 days are requested to please get themselves tested ! (sic).‚ÄùIn a tweet addressed to Sr Bachchan, Dhanush wrote, ‚ÄúGet well soon, sir, my sincere prayers for your speedy recovery (sic).‚ÄùIt‚Äôs worth mentioning that Dhanush and Amitabh Bachchan have shared screen space in the former‚Äôs Bollywood venture, which was directed by R Balki. Interestingly, the title Shamitabh was taken from the two actor‚Äôs names ‚Äì Sh from Dhanush and Amitabh from Amitabh. The film narrated the story of a mute man who becomes a star of the matinee world with the help of a rejected, aged actor, who lends the former his voice. The two actors have always had mutual respect for each other. During promotions, Dhanush had said that working with Big B had taught him a lot, and Amitabh had also said that he has great admiration for Dhanush.

Title: England vs West Indies, 1st Test: Windies' quicks strike as England collapse
Content:
England's Ollie Pope, second right, leaves the field after being dismissed by West Indies' Shannon Gabriel. (A... Read More

SOUTHAMPTON: Alzarri Joseph struck twice and West Indies captain Jason Holder removed England stand-in skipper Ben Stokes as the tourists regained the initiative in the first Test with a late flurry of wickets at Southampton on Saturday.

England were 284/8 in their second innings at the close of the fourth day, a lead of 170 runs in a match that marks international cricket's return from lockdown.

England fought back during a fourth-wicket partnership of 98 between Zak Crawley and Stokes.

But their 249/4 was soon transformed into 279/8 as five wickets fell for just 30 runs inside the final hour.

No sooner had Stokes fallen, then Crawley was caught and bowled by paceman Joseph for a Test-best 76.

Suddenly, England's two batsmen at the crease - Pope and Jos Buttler -- were both on nought.

Buttler, who overturned being lbw to Holder for five, fell for nine when bowled through a huge gap between bat and pad by Joseph.

World Cup-winning wicketkeeper Buttler has now made just one hundred in his 42 Tests.

And there was still time before the close for Windies spearhead quick Shannon Gabriel (3-62) to bowl both Dom Bess and Ollie Pope.

England were still one run behind West Indies' first innings 318 when Crawley came to the crease.

But the 22-year-old, in his fifth Test, completed a well-made fifty when he reverse-swept off-spinner Roston Chase for four.

Crawley, now facing the new ball, topped his previous Test best of 66 against South Africa at Johannesburg in January.

Stokes, skippering the side in the absence of Joe Root, continued to lead from the front by driving Gabriel for four.

The all-rounder had already top-scored with 43 in England's meagre first-innings 204 before the paceman was the pick of the hosts' attack with 4-49.

But for the second time in the match he fell to Holder.

The towering West Indies paceman squared Stokes up and had him caught by Shai Hope, cleverly positioned as the finer of two men in the gully for the left-handed batsman.

It was a tactical as well as personal triumph for Holder, ranked ahead of Stokes as the world's leading Test all-rounder.

There was more joy for the Windies when Crawley, aiming legside, was caught and bowled by Joseph.

England resumed on 15/0 in the first of a three-match behind closed doors series.

Although a batting all-rounder, Chase had taken a Test-best 8-60 when West Indies beat England at his Barbados home ground last year en route to a 2-1 series win.

Chase made the initial breakthrough on Saturday when Rory Burns (42) carelessly cut him to backward point.

Fellow opener Dom Sibley made a painstaking fifty off 161 balls.

The very next delivery saw Sibley play on to Gabriel only for third umpire Michael Gough to rule the bowler had been guilty of a marginal no-ball.

But, two balls later, Sibley - still on 50 -- glanced Gabriel to Dowrich as he was yet again caught down the legside in his fledgling Test career.

Joe Denly, potentially competing for a place with Sibley when Root returns following the birth of his daughter for next week's second Test at Old Trafford, needed a big score to bolster a lowly Test average of under 30.

But instead he fell tamely for 29 when chipping Chase to Holder at short midwicket.

The West Indies had been on top for most of this match, with Holder taking a Test-best 6-42 after losing the toss.

Kraigg Brathwaite then made 65, the opener's first Test fifty in 22 innings, and Dowrich 61 as the tourists established a valuable first-innings lead of 114.

Title: Sushant Singh Rajput suicide: Yuvika Chaudhary demands justice; says 'want to know the actual reason behind his death'
Content: Bollywood star Sushant Singh Rajput ‚Äôs sudden demise sent shockwaves across the nation and has left his family, friends, and fans disheartened. While many are taking to social media to revisit memories of the Dhoni actor, there are several actors who are demanding justice.Actress Yuvika Chaudhary is the latest one who has demanded justice. She took to her Instagram account and shared a story. She posted a message wherein she mentioned that the topic shouldn‚Äôt be shut and people should get to know the actual reason. She also added that proof should be shown to the people only then would his soul rest in peace.Take a look at the post:Yuvika is not the only actor, who has come forward to demand justice. Earlier actors like Shekhar Suman and recently Tarun Khanna had also expressed that there should be a proper investigation of the case and had even slammed Sushant‚Äôs ‚Äòfriend‚Äô Sandiip Singh.Sushant, who started his career with TV forayed into Bollywood with Kai Po Che and since then had no looking back. He gave hit films one after the other and was one of the promising actors of Hindi film industry.Sushant Singh Rajput died by suicide on June 14 at his Bandra residence in Mumbai. His passing away came as a shock to everyone. Post his death, many have spoken about nepotism in Bollywood which leads outsiders to take such a huge step.

Actress Pranutan Bahl, who made her Bollywood debut with ‚ÄòNotebook‚Äô last year, has been quite active on social media. She has been sharing pics of hers in various looks on Instagram. And now, the actress has shared a funny post of her ‚Äútrying to be active‚Äù on Twitter.Here, take a look at her tweet:Coming to her cinematic debut, ‚ÄòNotebook‚Äô, the film was directed by Nitin Kakkar and produced by none other than Salman Khan . A remake of the popular Thai film ‚ÄòThe Teacher‚Äôs Diary‚Äô, it also marked the Bollywood debut of Zaheer Iqbal. Films are not alien to Pranutan, who is an industry kid. Her father is actor Mohnish Bhal , while late actress Nutan is her grandmother.On the work front, Pranutan will next be seen on screen in ‚ÄòHelmet‚Äô opposite Aparshakti Khurana . The actress had said that unlike ‚ÄòNotebook‚Äô, which was a romance, ‚ÄòHelmet‚Äô is a fun and comedy movie. The movie, whose shoot was almost complete before the nationwide lockdown was announced, also has a message. Directed by Satram Ramani, the film has been co-produced by Dino Morea.

Title: Locked out of their businesses again
Content:
financial distress

spa business

(From top) Shital Hotel‚Äôs owner Vishwanath Shetty, hairdresser Anand Korhalkar and rickshaw driver Nikesh Gaikwad are few of the many anxious people, who may suffer financial losses due to impending lockdown

staff safety

The revert to lockdown could not have been more damning for commercial entities and service providers who had just begun struggling to get back on their feet. The worst-hit are restaurateurs and salon owners, who‚Äôd just invested on their reopening, only to be shut again. Similarly, autorickshaw drivers and cabbies were hoping to see their income pick up this month after losing almost three months‚Äô income.Though relaxations started mid-June, the government continued to restrict several sectors until July, with the spread of COVID-19 persisting. At the start of this month, the state government relented, showing inclination to unlock more sectors. The salon andwas given permission to resume operations from June 28. But, barely a week into their operations they are faced with another round of having to pull down their shutters.Anand Korhalkar, owner of Passion Unisex Salon on Sinhagad Road, had just invested on PPE kits, sanitisers and thermal scanners, so he could reopen his salon last Sunday.‚ÄúAfter the unlocking was announced and we were given permission to resume operations, I purchased all the merchandise needed to ensure customer and. In the one week gone by, we hardly had any footfall but I hung in there in the hope that the business will pick up next week. But now it‚Äôs back to lockdown,‚Äù he recounted.The fresh lockdown has spelled doom for Ajit Thakur, who runs Archana Men‚Äôs Parlour on Paud Road in Kothrud, and he is pushed to considering exiting the business. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs been no revenue since March and yet I had to keep paying salaries to my staff. Now even the shop owner is demanding rent. When we were allowed to reopen last Sunday, I‚Äôd assured the shop owner that I‚Äôd start paying the rent regularly from next month. But the new lockdown has broken my back and I have to consider closing shop completely.‚ÄùWhile salons could operate for at least a week, restaurants that were just gearing to up their shutters have been robbed of that opportunity by the lockdown coming up. ‚ÄúWhen the government announced that there would be no further lockdowns, restaurateurs were encouraged to restock on their raw materials which are perishables, in anticipation of being back in the business. We got permission to reopen only a few days ago, but now the lockdown has come upon us,‚Äù pointed out Ganesh Shetty, president of Pune Restaurant and Hoteliers‚Äô Association.Worse, some even called back their staff from their native places in preparation to restart the business. ‚ÄúI called back my staff after the government gave permission. Now that they are here, they cannot go back and I will have to pay them though there will be no income. We‚Äôre doing parcel service but the business is just too lean,‚Äù said Vishwanath Shetty, owner of Sheetal Hotel on Karve Road.Apart from these businesses, service providers such as autorickshaw drivers and cabbies, who hardly have any financial muscle and were hit by the threemonth long lockdown, are equally devastated by the return to restriction. ‚ÄúI am the sole breadwinner of the family and my income comes purely from driving my rickshaw. With the relaxation, I resumed plying in June but given that people were still keeping off the streets, my income was barely Rs 100-200 a day. Only recently the mobility of citizens had improved and I was expecting July to be more remunerative but the announcement of yet another lockdown has brought on the horrors of struggling through without income that we experienced earlier. Before imposing another lockdown, the government should have given some thought to the financial condition of people like us,‚Äù cried 35-year-old Nikesh Gaikwad from Katraj.Cabbies echo that the new lockdown could not have been more illtimed. ‚ÄúCab services suffered huge losses these past months. Even pursuant to the relaxation people were wary of taking cabs with the threat of the virus still hanging over their heads. With things beginning to return to a certain normalcy we were pinning our hopes on better income in July. But the dream of recuperation has been squashed by the fresh diktat. Clearly, the government has not spared a thought to the plight of the poor,‚Äù alleged Jitendra Kamble, a cab driver residing in Vishrantwadi.

Title: Police bust weekend parties in Aarey Colony, book 33 people
Content:
wearing masks

social distance

weekend parties

Disaster Management Act

Epidemic Diseases Act

The party-goers were not, or keeping, say officials.Police raided several bungalows at the Royal Palms in Aarey Colony on Saturday where people were attendingand booked 33 under theas well as the Indian Penal Code.Residents of the colony alerted police at around 7.30 pm about parties at four villas.The party-goers were not wearing masks, or keeping social distance; they were also found swimming in pools, sub-inspector Vinod Patil said. ‚ÄúWe could round up 33 people from four bungalows, who are from all over the city. Some are also residents of Gujarat,‚Äù he said.Senior inspector Nutan Pawar said the police were trying to establish whether the owners of the bungalows knew about the parties.‚ÄúAccording to the residents of the area, at least 150 people came to these bungalows in the afternoon. Since these are villas that people usually rent out for weekends, this is not a new thing. All through the lockdown, similar smaller parties have been raided by the police,‚Äù said Ujjwala Modal, the local corporator. Modal said she was surprised that despite the lockdown, so many people could enter the area.One of the complainants who became the police's witness on the official records criminologist Snehil Dhall said that three of the four bungalows belongs to a doctor working with the BMC. "Having four doctors in one family and owning three villas it was expected to maintain discipline but still they not just gave their properties for renting but also encouraged other non-medical professionals to rent for weekend parties," he said.Dhall further said that a total of six villas were raided that were owned by three different individuals. "There were other villas where parties were being conducted but the police could not raid there due to heavy rains. Also, the revelers there had already run away after hearing about the police raids," he said.

Title: Iqbal Khan: Why should schools charge fees for the facilities students are not using?
Content: Over the past few weeks, parents across the country have spoken out against schools for not changing their fee structure during this tough phase. Recently, there were reports of some parents filing a plea in the Supreme Court, seeking moratorium or deferment of payment of fee during the COVID-19 pandemic . They also requested that schools charge fees based on their actual expenditure till the commencement of normal classes Actor Iqbal Khan has also been raising the issue in his own way. A couple of days ago, he posted a video on how eighty percent private schools in our country have not offered any fee deduction, despite classes being conducted online due to the COVID-19 crisis.Iqbal, whose daughter will now enter Class IV, told BT, ‚ÄúIt is unfair. Even if they pay the teachers, who are working from home, schools don‚Äôt have to ply their buses, run canteens or use electricity in classrooms. Some private schools are even charging for food, swimming pool and track-and-field ‚Äî facilities no student has availed over the past few months. Why should parents pay for the services that our children are not using? However, even after repeated requests, most schools refuse to reduce the fees.‚ÄùWhen asked about the video, he said, ‚ÄúMany parents have paid the fees without any complaints. I think everyone should stand united in situations like these, as our demands are absolutely fair and justified. I want to appeal to fellow parents to support the cause and hence, the video.‚ÄùMeanwhile, the actor is happy that his alma mater in Kasauli is a rare exception. He said, ‚ÄúThe boarding school where I studied, has reduced fees by 30 percent fees. That too, when teachers live on the campus and use facilities like accommodation and mess. If they can reduce fees, why can‚Äôt the schools in our city follow suit?‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúDuring this tough phase, everyone has accepted pay cuts. Maybe, our schools, too, should think less about business.‚Äù

Title: Sanitise my makeup room, carry my dabba, use a pair of masks: Aneri Vajani
Content:
SUBSCRIBE NOW

Get a weekly dose of all the major happenings in the TV world, right in your inbox every Friday.

Title: PMC chief shifted in sudden shuffle
Content:
Shekhar Gaikwad

Pune Municipal Corporation

coronavirus

MP Bapat opposes new city lockdown



Bharatiya Janata Party

BJP

Girish Bapat

Amid declaration of another lockdown for 10 days and several protests from citizens, the state government on Saturday issued unexpected orders of transfers of top Indian Administrative Service (IAS) officers from city.Shekhar Gaikwad, who till now was(PMC) commissioner, has been made the new state sugar commissioner, just five months after he took charge. Vikram Kumar, who was serving as commissioner of Pune Metropolitan Region Development Authority (PMRDA), will now be the new PMC commissioner.Gaikwad served as the sugar commissioner before he was transferred to the PMC. State agriculture commissioner Suhas Divase will be the new metropolitan commissioner of PMRDA, replacing Kumar.Saurabh Rao, who was the sugar commissioner, will be taking charge of the Pune divisional commissioner‚Äôs office as officer on special duty (OSD). Rao is likely to replace Deepak Mhaisekar, the current divisional commissioner who is going to retire by the end of July. This is the fourth consecutive tenure of Rao in Pune.The transfer of Gaikwad is reportedly an outcome of alleged failure in controlling the outbreak of, despite freedom given to him by the state government. He was also allegedly against imposition of the new lockdown. A 2003-batch IAS officer, Gaik-wad has served on various posts, including commissioner of the groundwater survey and development authority, district collector of Sangli and chief executive officer of Thane Zilla Parishad.) leader and Member of Parliament (MP) from the city,, on Saturday opposed the plan for a new lockdown plan and claimed that he was kept in the dark about it by deputy chief minister Ajit Pawar and the district administration.He said, ‚ÄúThe administration should also take strict action against individuals who are found not wearing masks and not following social distancing. But why is the government punishing 97 per cent of Punekars for the 3 per cent not following norms? This decision is being taken by just on the advice of bureaucrats.‚ÄùBapat also questioned the strategy adopted by the government, saying, ‚ÄúOn one side you issue orders for unlocking the state, on other side you lockdown acity like Pune, what kind of strategy is this?‚Äù

Title: Karnataka is high on Old Mysore region
Content:
Mysore

brewery hubs

beer capital

Karnataka

..

famous brands

By Sudeshna Duttaand Hassan emerge asfor their logistical advantage, access to clean water and availability of landWhile microbreweries are all the rage in Bengaluru, theof India, breweries of your favourite bottled beers have found their home away from the city. Mysuru and Hassan inare fast becoming the go-to destinations which are looking attractive to brewery owners.Thomas Hartman, VP ‚Äì Innovation & Brewing, Bira 91, says, ‚ÄúMysuru has given us a strategic advantage in terms of brewery location, and we are able to cater to a large part of our volume through this. Not only that, the brewery also houses our first-ever innovation lab for flavourful new beers.‚Äù He says their ingredients are locally sourced from India and some are imported from Europe and the USA.‚ÄúAdditionally, the water at all our breweries is filtered and run through reverse osmosis, effectively rendering it pure H2O before use. From there, our brewers add select minerals in our beers to ensure consistency in taste across all four breweries in Mysuru, Kovvur in Andhra Pradesh, Nagpur in Maharashtra and Indore in Madhya Pradesh,‚Äù says Hartman. They have installed a pilot system, which allows brewers to brew beers in smaller batches, play around with new ideas, and also send those beers to Bira Taproom in Bengaluru and receive direct consumer feedback.Javed Murad, founder, White Owl, which manufactures its products at a partner-owned brewery in Hassan, says some of the immediate perks of this plant include shorter supply chain lead time, lower logistics costs and in certain cases, savings on various state-to-state import and export duties, all of which enable brands to provide more competitive end-pricing to consumers. "We are currently brewing our two most popular beer styles in Hassan -- Spark, a refreshing Belgian Wit, and Spike, our smooth Weizenbock, which is a strong craft beer. However, we expect to add more of our brands to the mix once our kegging line is activated at the plant over the next few months. At that point, supply will expand not just within Karnataka but also to the rest of the country, especially to markets in Goa, Telangana and Maharashtra," adds Murad.AB InBev‚Äôs SPR brewery situated in the town of T Narasipura, which is about 45 minutes away from Mysuru, brews some of the world‚Äôs most: Budweiser, Budweiser Magnum, Beck‚Äôs Ice and Beck‚Äôs Ice Premium Lager, specialty wheat beers Veere and Machaa from 7Rivers Brewing Co. as well as regional favourites like Knock Out, Royal Challenge and Foster‚Äôs, to name a few.‚ÄúBrewing beer requires access to clean and affordable water supply to meet production demands, and the city is well-placed with its access to quality water resources. Owing to its Infrastructural facilities and availability of 60 acres of land, Mysuru was our best bet,‚Äù says Gagandeep Sethi, VP Supply & Logistics ‚Äì South Asia, AB InBev. The brewery in Mysuru is also the first among their breweries in India to adopt renewable electricity to power its operations.‚ÄúThis initiative is part of our global commitment to secure 100 per cent of the company‚Äôs electricity from renewable sources by 2025. We signed a long-term Power Purchase Agreement in 2018 to make the shift to green electricity. Within just two years, SPR has achieved over 65 per cent renewable electricity adoption, successfully reducing its carbon footprint by over 3.5 million kg,‚Äù says Sethi.Apart from global exports, SPR also transports its products to Pondicherry and Kerala. From a manufacturing point of view, the brewery has been built in such a way that can cater to the larger hubs of Mysuru, Bengaluru and other parts of Karnataka.

Title: Seven detained in Mahisagar for partying in pandemic
Content:
Mahisagar police

video

liquor

Gujarat

Theon Saturday arrested seven persons, reportedly workers of the BJP, after aof a birthday bash whereflowed freely, social distancing was disregarded and a huge cake was cut with a sword went viral.Apparently, cutting cakes with a sword has become the new norm for manifestation of power inand celebrations include consumption of liquor in a state that prides itself of being a dry state.According to sources, the occasion was BJP youth leader Kavan Patel‚Äôs birthday with a party being organised by Yogendra Mehra, a BJP functionary. Revellers did not wear masks and social distancing was completely neglected as is apparent from the video.The police said they had arrested Kavan Patel, Yogendra Mehra and five others who celebrated the birthday.DySP confirms arrestMahisagar DySP N V Patel said, ‚ÄúWe have arrested Kavan Patel, Yogendra Mehra and five others based on the video that went viral. We are also in the process of identifying others who were at the party and will duly arrest them. The sword with which the cake was cut has been seized and the accused have been arrested for offences including prohibition, violation of notification and Epidemic Diseases Act for not wearing masks and failure to maintain social distance.‚ÄùWhen asked if the accused belonged to the BJP, Patel said he was not aware of the party affiliation of the accused.

Title: Sale of ‚Äòimmunity-boosting‚Äô plants increases in Covid-19 times
Content:
Ragini Chandel with her plants (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Science behind the immunity-booster plants

With a lot of stress being given to raise immunity levels to fight COVID 19 infection, the sale of immunity boosting plants has upped manifold in the past few months. Some of the nurseries in the city are over selling these immunity boosting plants over ornamental ones which till now had formed the major chunk of the earnings of these nurseries.Shyamji Patel, who runs a plant nursery in Manduadih area in Varanasi, says, ‚ÄúMore than 50 percent of the customers who come to buy plants now want herbal ones. Among these, Giloy and Ashwagandha tops the list. In fact, we have run out of stock of Ashwagandha saplings as the demand is so high. Ever since concoction or kadha of these herbs is being promoted from various platforms to keep the virus at bay, people are planting them in their homes.‚ÄùAiring a similar view is JP Sharma , a senior staff at Chandra Shekhar Azad Park (Company Bagh), Prayagraj, ‚ÄúWe sell at least 100 saplings of Ashwagandha plants everyday. Earlier our focus was mainly on ornamental and fruit plants but off late we have also started focusing on medicinal plants as well due to the increased demand. Other medicinal plants like giloy, neem, aloe vera, said to improve the general health conditions, also have a lot of buyers.‚Äù Ragini Chandel with her plants (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)‚ÄúThe best part is most of these medicinal plants can be planted even in pots and do not require much garden space. So it is convenient for people to own these plants and use their leaves or stems, as the case may be, rather than use them in their bottled form available in the market. There is a 50 percent surge in such customers wanting these plants,‚Äù says Mahesh Maurya, owner of a nursery in Varanasi.Ragini Chandel, a businesswoman in Prayagraj, says, ‚ÄúEver since the outbreak of the pandemic I drink a concoction of herbs or kadha twice a day for which I recently added giloy. A dash of lemon grass, another herb which I also have, in the kadha not only boosts up the immunity but also removes stress, which nearly everyone is feeling due to the present conditions.‚ÄùSimilarly Varanasi based homemaker Gauri Kedia planted a sapling of ajwain and giloy in her garden in the beginning of the lockdown. ‚ÄúNow I use these plants in the concoction to raise the immunity of my family since it is believed people with better immunity are at lower risk to catch the infection.‚ÄùEarlier this year, a research in the US found possible benefits of some vitamins, trace elements and probiotics ‚Äì including those found in certain plants and herbs ‚Äì in combating viral infections, concluding that these principles could be useful in possible prevention and management of COVID-19. In India, the Ministry of AYUSH has sought details from traditional medicine practitioners to suggest techniques and therapies based on herbal and plant-based remedies to combat COVID-19.

Ragini Chandel with her plants (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)

Title: Packed stadiums, crowds, intimacy: Will VFX solve shooting dilemmas?
Content: Over the last decade, VFX (visual effects) has played an increasingly prominent role in Bollywood films. And, in the current normal that we are all living in, we will probably see filmmakers leaning more towards VFX to bring the desired impact in their movies. In keeping with safety norms, filmmakers are chalking out ways to involve fewer people on the sets of a film, thus opening more doors for VFX teams to play a bigger role in the narrative, especially when it comes to sequences involving outdoor locations, elaborate dance numbers, action scenes and large crowds. In a recent chat with BT, filmmaker R Balki said, ‚ÄúI think VFX technology will play a huge role in our cinema now. It‚Äôs going to explode in this country like it never has before. So, I think newer ways of designing things in our films‚Ä¶ in fact, technology is going to play a huge part in filmmaking right now.‚ÄúThis period will throw up a lot of innovative ideas for filmmaking using VFX. In fact, it will make visible changes in the way TV, gaming and advertising industries function. With precise planning, VFX can be a tool for filmmakers to make the shooting process more convenient. Crowd scenes were always a part of VFX, and now, we can try to create intimate scenes using technology. But I doubt if a full-scale CGI (Computer-Generated Imagery) will be worth the effort in most cases, as it adds to the expense,‚Äù said Naveen Paul (co-founder and VFX supervisor at NY vfxwaala), who has worked on the special effects for movies like 'Tanhaji: The Unsung Warrior'.Keitan Yadav (COO, Redchillies VFX) believes that the future of cinema lies in virtual production. He cited examples of films like 'The Lion King' and 'The Mandalorian' series, which were shot using virtual production technology. It was also employed for parts of the Shah Rukh Khan-starrer, 'Zero'. He shared, ‚ÄúFilmmakers can use this technology at the pre-production stage, for planning and organising the shoot schedule. This will reduce the number of days required for shoots, save cost and ensure smooth execution of shoots. It will reduce VFX work and improve quality within the pre-decided budget.‚Äù Harry Hingorani (VFX supervisor and creative officer of the company) added, ‚ÄúVFX companies are the ones, who will be able to help filmmakers adapt to these changes. We recently got a call from a producer, saying that he was half way through the film before the lockdown. They have 50-plus days of shoot pending, including a big sequence that requires them to go out of Mumbai. Since they can‚Äôt do that, we are getting into virtual production with them.‚ÄùProducer Nikkhil Advani , whose films 'Bell Bottom' and 'Satyameva Jayate 2' will go on floors in the weeks to come, said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs extremely short-sighted to see VFX as a solution for shoots post lockdown. You will still have to send a unit to the location to take plates. Also, if it needs to be done correctly, it means matching light conditions, camera angles and depth of field. In India, we have constantly used VFX as a tool for correction, while it actually needs to be used for creation. If VFX has to be an option to shoot at interesting locations and scenes with crowds, it will become imperative to give more time to prep for each of those sequences.‚ÄùFilmmaker Rahul Dholakia, who will be helming Taapsee Pannu ‚Äôs 'Shabaash Mithu', the biopic on cricketer Mithali Raj , shared, ‚ÄúVFX will become very important for me, because, without it, how do I show jam-packed stadiums? Also, we may not be able to go to various locations because of revised budgets and other constraints; so, VFX will have to help us. And as far as the narrative is concerned, I don‚Äôt think VFX is the only player; rewriting screenplays to adhere to shooting guidelines will play an important role.‚ÄùProducer Boney Kapoor agreed, ‚ÄúVFX was already playing a vital role, and now, its importance will increase further. In our film 'Maidaan', we have to create a certain ‚Äòperiod‚Äô as well as different football stadiums. So, VFX will play a substantial role. I do see it becoming a stronger part of the narrative if it helps save cost and enhances quality. But I know that live action and VFX cannot replace each other beyond a certain level. So, we will use VFX as much as possible, especially in times of COVID-19, because the safety of cast and crew is most important.‚ÄùVoicing an important concern, he added, ‚ÄúIn terms of investment and recovery, I believe that VFX studios will also have to rethink their pricing. If they want to get the bulk of the work, they will have to deliver on pricing as well as quality, as we are all interdependent. There are many countries that offer rebates and incentives for post-production, and that‚Äôs something that can be a huge opportunity for Indian post-production industry as well.‚Äù

Title: Covid-19: India‚Äôs share in daily global cases now 12%
Content: NEW DELHI: India‚Äôs Covid-19 caseload crossed 8.5 lakh, a day after going past the 8 lakh mark, as the country added another record number of cases on Saturday ‚Äî nearly 29,000 ‚Äî with the daily count of fresh infections touching a new peak for the fourth day in a row.The day‚Äôs death toll was 540, the second-highest single-day rise in deaths so far, discounting the 2,003 mostly back-dated fatalities added on June 16.The rapid spread of the pandemic this week has upped India‚Äôs share in daily global cases to nearly 12%.India accounted for 11.8% of the total daily cases worldwide on Friday (averaged over three days) despite the global numbers touching a new high of nearly 2.37 lakh, as per the worldometers.info website.India‚Äôs share in global cases has been steadily rising since at least early June, although it‚Äôs still less than the country‚Äôs share in the world‚Äôs population, which is more than 17.5%.However, a comparison of weekly numbers (three-day averages) in the past five weeks shows that the spike on June 10 was the sharpest, with India‚Äôs share going up by 1.3 percentage points over June 3, when the share was 10.5%. In other words, while global Covid-19 cases are rising sharply, India‚Äôs growth rate is higher than the international average.On Saturday, fresh Covid-19 cases across the country surged to 28,998, just two short of the 29,000 mark, as per data collated from state governments. India‚Äôs total caseload stood at 8,50,052, while the cumulative death toll was 22,664.

Title: Get well soon Amitabh and Abhishek Bachchan: Riteish Deshmukh, Sayali Sanjeev and other Marathi celebs wish the stars a speedy recovery
Content:
T 3590 -I have tested CoviD positive .. shifted to Hospital .. hospital informing authorities .. family and staf‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Brl0qhPQx0 ‚Äî Amitabh Bachchan (@SrBachchan) 1594488178000

Get well soon sir @SrBachchan - praying for your good health & speedy recovery. https://t.co/HPwhH9HNdO ‚Äî Riteish Deshmukh (@Riteishd) 1594488398000

Praying for your speedy recovery @SrBachchan sir https://t.co/XUSbVJPDqx ‚Äî Renuka Shahane (@renukash) 1594489855000

Bollywood's megastar Amitabh Bachchan and son, Abhishek Bachchan has tested positive for the coronavirus. According to the reports, the legendary actor was admitted to Mumbai‚Äôs Nanavati hospital on Saturday.The actors took to their Twitter handle to share the news of their fans about their diagnosis.In his Twitter handle Amitabh Bachchan gave detail about his condition and wrote "I have tested CoviD positive .. shifted to Hospital .. hospital informing authorities .. family and staff undergone tests , results awaited .. All that have been in close proximity to me in the last 10 days are requested to please get themselves tested !"As soon as the legendary shared the post on Twitter, celebs from Marathi film industry like Riteish Deshmukh, Sayali Sanjeev and many others have sent their prayers and well wishes for Amitabh Bachchan and son, Abhishek Bachchan.Bollywood and Marathi cinema 's popular actor Riteish Deshmukh wished Amitabh a speedy recovery on Twitter, saying "Get well soon sir @SrBachchan - praying for your good health & speedy recovery."

Title: Riddhima Kapoor Sahni rubbishes rumours of Ranbir Kapoor, Karan Johar and Neetu Kapoor testing positive for COVID-19
Content:
Read Also

Read Also

Read Also

After Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan and son Abhishek Bachchan announced they have both tested positive for COVID-19 , rumours began doing the rounds suggesting that Ranbir Kapoor Neetu Kapoor and director Karan Johar had also contracted the virus.The baseless rumour went viral on and off social media, claiming that the three contracted the virus as Bachchan‚Äôs grandson Agastya Nanda had attended Neetu‚Äôs birthday party early this week that was hosted by Riddhima.Shutting down the false report, Riddhima took to her handle and set the record straight saying, ‚ÄúPlease verify and clarify before you tweet! We are all good! Thank you very much!‚ÄùSharing the same on her handle, she said, "Attention seeking ??? Least verify/ clarify ! We are fit We are good ! Stop spreading rumours ! #lunatics"This confirmation comes in shortly after both Amitabh and Abhishek issued statements on their official handles to inform those who were in close proximity with them, to get themselves tested.‚ÄúThis evening I tested positive for COVID 19 .. have been shifted to Hospital .. authorities informed .. family and staff tested results awaited .. all those that came in close proximity to me in the last 10 days please get yourself tested,‚Äù said Amitabh while sharing a photo of himself.The veteran star has been admitted to Nanavati Hospital in Mumbai where he has been seeking treatment and undergoing tests.While informing fans that his father and he have ‚Äúmild symptoms‚Äù he asked people not to panic and ‚Äústay calm‚Äù. Abhishek tweeted, "Earlier today both my father and I tested positive for COVID 19. Both of us having mild symptoms have been admitted to hospital. We have informed all the required authorities and our family and staff are all being tested. I request all to stay calm and not panic. Thank you."He went on to add, ‚ÄúThe BMC has been in touch and we are complying with them."Following the announcement, fans, friends and Bollywood film stars have been offering their prayers and wishing the father-son duo a speedy recovery.Amitabh has been leading the way in India‚Äôs fight against the coronavirus , by appearing in public service advertisements and also doing his bit on a personal level by reaching out to those in need.

Title: Exclusive! From Jay Bhatt to Viral Shah: Gujarati celebs pray for Bollywood stars Amitabh Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan
Content: While everyone is trying to get used to the new normal of living with protection to stay safe from the Coronavirus, the virus is continuing to spread across the world and one after the other, one and all are falling prey to it. As per latest reports, Bollywood veteran Amitabh Bachchan and his son Abhishek Bachchan have tested positive for the virus and everyone from Indian cinema has been sending their well wishes for the family. From Jay Bhatt to Viral Shah, even Gujarati stars are praying for the stars.Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan earlier tweeted about being hospitalised for coronavirus and reports say that even his son Abhishek has tested positive for the virus. According to reports, the veteran star has been rushed to Nanavati hospital in Mumbai and even Dhollywood stars are praying for the star‚Äôs health.Jay Bhatt has shared, "It's necessary to understand that COVID-19 has penetrated largely and it will find its way in whichever way possible. Prayers for a speedy recovery for all those affected." Hemang Dave said, "In a series of sad news, one more added today that Senior Bachchan Sir And Junior Bachchan Sir both are tested Corona positive. Me and all their fans have started praying for the fastest recovery of their health and I am very sure they will come home soon and will start entertaining us again with full energy. Just today, I completed watching Abhishek Bachchan‚Äôs web series and he is just amazing. I request everyone to pray for them." Jimit Trivedi shares: "My prayers for speedy recovery of Amit ji & Abhishek ji ... May they both recover fast & bounce back soon & healthy." üôèüèªüíêüôåüèª Khushi Shah said, "I am urging you all. Please take precautions. This virus is not looking for poor and rich people, it is attacking everyone. This is my request to everyone please, oh please, stay safe. Not just for the sake of your health, but others as well. I am sending my prayers for Amitabh sir and Abhishek too." Rehan Chaudhary said: "It is saddening to hear that legendary actor Amitabh and junior Bachchan both have tested positive for COVOD-19. I wish them a speedy recovery and hope that no one else tests positive who had come in contact with them. This is a tough time for all of us and we shall all get through this soon. It's my humble request to everyone to stay indoors and take the necessary precautions for safety purposes."Pooja Jhaveri: "It feels like the darkest cloud has covered the film industry ! The living legend having contracted Covid.. it isn‚Äôt sad it is heartbreaking.... but all in all what we can take from this is... you or I anyone can get it.. #bemindful #besafe Praying for the speedy recovery of the living legend... Amitabh Bachchan and Abhishek Bachchan." Hardik Sanghani added, "This is the most shocking news. Mr. Bachchan is like the synonym for Bollywood. The country prayed even when he was injured during the shoot of coolie and is praying now as well. I wish him and Abhishek a speedy recovery." Bharat Chawda shared, "Amitabhji is a Living Legend. He is an idol to millions and an iconic superstar. We have faith in their ability to fight back this virus. I am sure the whole nation is praying for their speedy recovery and sending positive vibes. I want to urge people to stay indoors and take utmost care, nothing is more important than health."Viral Shah said, "It was shocking to hear about both Mr. Bachchan junior and senior. But I guess we have to accept the fact that this virus is here to stay for a while. And we have to keep dodging it by following all precautionary measures like steam twice a day and consume immunity boosters. Apart from that, I urge everyone to keep checking their oxygen levels with an oximeter everyday. That‚Äôs the only best way to detect it at an early stage and save oneself from any major damage."

Title: Haryana's Covid-19 count spirals, crosses 20,000-mark
Content: CHANDIGARH: Haryana's Covid-19 count on Saturday crossed 20,000-mark as 648 new patients and seven deaths took the state total to 20,582 cases and 297 casualties. Meanwhile, 490 new recoveries have taken the overall recoveries to 5,394.Notably, it took almost four months to reach the 5k figure on June 9 and then June 20, Haryana's Covid count had crossed 10,000-mark. It took 20 more days when the count crossed the 20K-mark on Saturday.Now, Haryana has 4,891 active patients that include 79 critical ones. Of the seven deaths, three are from Faridabad, two from Sonipat and one each from Gurugram and Nuh districts.According to sources, Gurugram topped the table with 170 new patients and one death. Overall count has gone up to 6,728 patients with 104 deaths. There are total 1,035 active cases in the district.After Gurugram, it is Sonipat where 110 new patients have been reported, Here the total has gone up to 1,888 with 676 active cases. Faridabad had 90 new patients with overall count going up to 5,198 with 101 deaths. With 4,245 recoveries, Faridabad has total 852 active cases.As many as 56 new patients have come from Rewari, 42 from Ambala, 31 from Hisar, 28 from Jhajjar district, 21 from Panipat, 20 from Palwal, 18 from Mahindergarh and 14 from Bhiwani, 12 each from Karnal and Nuh, nine from Kurukshetra, six from Sirsa, five from Panchkula and four from Fateahabd.Meanwhile, 3,63,428 persons have been tested so far.

Title: Punjab records 231 new Covid-19 cases, 8 deaths
Content: Chandigarh: As Punjab recorded 231 new cases on Saturday, the total number of Covid-19 patients reached 7,587 in the state. The state also lost eight lives to the pandemic on Saturday, taking its toll to 195.Punjab rural development minister Tript Rajinder Singh Bajwa's sample came negative. The cabinet minister had got himself tested after rural development director Vipul Ujjwal, who had attended meetings with Bajwa, had tested positive on Friday.Two Covid-19 positive patients each breathed their last in Patiala and Jalandhar. Whereas Pathankot, Sangrur, Ludhiana and Bathinda districts registered one death each.The highest number of 77 Covid positive patients were reported on Saturday from Jalandhar district, followed by 55 in Patiala, 29 in Ludhiana, 19 in Amritsar and 12 in Mohali district. Similarly, eight samples tested positive in Ferozepur district, seven in Sangrur, six in Nawanshahr, five in Moga and three in Faridkot. Results of two samples each came positive in Barnala, Fazilka and Fatehgarh Sahib districts. Bathinda and Hoshiarpur districts also got one new case each.Among the Covid positive patients reported on Saturday, there were three cops from Ludhiana and one from Patiala. Six positive cases of health care workers were reported from Ludhiana, three from Patiala and two from Barnala.At the same time, 23 patients were discharged from various hospitals in Punjab after their recovery on Saturday. Out of the total 2,352 Covid active cases in Punjab, Ludhiana is at the top with 674 cases, followed by Jalandhar with 486 cases, Patiala with 328, Amritsar with 172, Sangrur with 110 and Mohali with 104 cases.Amritsar district has recorded the highest number of 51 Covid deaths till now, followed by 31 in Ludhiana, 25 in Jalandhar, 18 in Sangrur and 12 in Patiala.

Title: 700 tourists visit Himachal Pradesh in five days
Content:
Shimla‚Äôs Mall Road packed as usual on Saturday

SHIMLA: After allowing entry of tourists into Himachal Pradesh, about 700 tourists visited the state in last five days. Interestingly, majority of hotels owners and their associations in Himachal Pradesh are against the idea of opening hotels for tourists from other states fearing they might be carriers of coronavirus.

The department of tourism and civil aviation has issued the standard operating procedure (SOPs) for opening of tourism units in the state. Secretary, tourism and civil sviation Devesh Kumar said before framing SOPs, the tourism department examined the procedures followed by other states who have also opened the hotels for tourists.

Kumar said according to the advisory issued, the tourists who wish to visit Himachal have to adhere to the guidelines issued by the state government. They have to register themselves on Covid-19 e-pass.hp.gov.in web portal 48 hours before visiting under tourist category, he added.

The tourists have to carry certificate (RTPCR) issued by ICMR certified laboratory with negative report and this should not be more than 72 hours. In addition, the tourist must have downloaded Aarogya Setu App on their mobiles.

Director of tourism & civil aviation Yunus said while entering the state, the tourists will be asked to show the medical report, confirmed booking for minimum five days in registered tourism units and Aarogya Setu app.

He said these measures are being adopted for the safety of tourists and others.

Title: Covid-19: 11 test positive in Himachal Pradesh, 22 recover
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

SHIMLA: Eleven new cases of Covid-19 were on Saturday detected in Himachal Pradesh , taking the number of positive cases in the state so far to 1,182. Total 22 positive patients were also reported to have recovered. Among the fresh cases, four were reported from Una district, three from Kangra, two from Solan and one person each tested positive for the virus in Hamirpur and Sirmaur districts.

With the latest additions, the total number of active cases of Covid-19 in the state stands at 263, while 895 patients have recovered so far, 13 migrated out of the state and nine died of the virus infection. Two positive patients died in Chamba and Shimla districts due to non-Covid reasons.

In Una, a six-year-old child is among the four positive cases reported from Saloh, Ambova and Gondpur areas in the district.In Kangra district, a 65-year-old male from Gharjarot village of Jawali tehsil, a primary contact of a Covid-positive patient, was tested positive. Another male, 37, from Nanau in Una district, who was brought to Dr Rajendra Prasad Government Medical College, Tanda, tested positive. The third patient is a 50-year-old man from Basa village, who had returned from Sangrur in Punjab on July 3 and was in institutional quarantine. In Sirmaur district, a 34-year-old Army jawan of Khera village, who had returned from Assam on July 5, has tested positive. In Hamirpur, a person from Kardoh village of Nadaun sub-division has been tested positive.

A total of 63,519 persons were put under surveillance in the state till Saturday, of them 43,127 have completed their 28 days of surveillance, while 20,392 are under active surveillance.

So far, 98,367 persons have been tested for Covid-19, of whom 97,104 have tested negative, while the results of 81 samples were awaited.

Title: Congress MPs chorus for Rahul as party chief
Content: NEW DELHI: With Sonia Gandhi‚Äôs term as ‚Äúinterim‚Äù Congress president nearing completion, a chorus of party MPs has broken out, demanding that Rahul Gandhi return to the helm of the organisation even as he keeps up his direct attacks on Prime Minister Narendra Modi over various issues ranging from handling of the Covid situation and confrontation with China in Ladakh.Interestingly, joining the debate on future party leadership on social media, veteran Digvijaya Singh questioned Rahul‚Äôs decision to step down as Congress chief and asked who was stopping him from returning to the top post during a virtual interaction between Sonia Gandhi and party MPs held on Saturday.Amid Rahul Gandhi‚Äôs attack on the PM, Congress members led by K Suresh, Manickam Tagore, Gaurav Gogoi, among others, demanded that the leader return as party president. They lauded Rahul‚Äôs role in exposing the ‚Äúgovernment‚Äôs failures‚Äù in the string of national crises where, they said, he had forced the government to respond.Sonia Gandhi‚Äôs current interim term, which began when Rahul insisted on stepping down after Congress‚Äô repeat debacle in the Lok Sabha elections, ends on August 10.The demand for Rahul‚Äôs return at the helm seems to be becoming a routine affair, with the meeting of Congress Working Committee last month witnessing a similar chorus. The issue was also raised in another CWC gathering, besides being mentioned regularly on public forums. But it seems to be gaining momentum and there might well be a push to ensure he returns.Digvijaya Singh questioned Rahul‚Äôs decision to step down after the election defeat. ‚ÄúHe had virtually emerged as the main challenger to Modi in 2019 and should have continued to build the party. Why did he voluntarily withdraw from the scene?‚Äù Singh tweeted. Singh said those leaders opposed to Rahul‚Äôs aggressive politics should quit the party.

Title: Congress MPs chorus for Rahul as party chief
Content:
NEW DELHI: With Sonia Gandhi‚Äôs term as ‚Äúinterim‚Äù Congress president nearing completion, a chorus of party MPs has broken out, demanding that Rahul Gandhi return to the helm of the organisation even as he keeps up his direct attacks on Prime Minister Narendra Modi over various issues ranging from handling of the Covid situation and confrontation with China in Ladakh.

Interestingly, joining the debate on future party leadership on social media, veteran Digvijaya Singh questioned Rahul‚Äôs decision to step down as Congress chief and asked who was stopping him from returning to the top post during a virtual interaction between Sonia Gandhi and party MPs held on Saturday.

Amid Rahul Gandhi‚Äôs attack on the PM, Congress members led by K Suresh, Manickam Tagore, Gaurav Gogoi, among others, demanded that the leader return as party president. They lauded Rahul‚Äôs role in exposing the ‚Äúgovernment‚Äôs failures‚Äù in the string of national crises where, they said, he had forced the government to respond.

Sonia Gandhi‚Äôs current interim term, which began when Rahul insisted on stepping down after Congress‚Äô repeat debacle in the Lok Sabha elections, ends on August 10.

The demand for Rahul‚Äôs return at the helm seems to be becoming a routine affair, with the meeting of Congress Working Committee last month witnessing a similar chorus. The issue was also raised in another CWC gathering, besides being mentioned regularly on public forums. But it seems to be gaining momentum and there might well be a push to ensure he returns.

Digvijaya Singh questioned Rahul‚Äôs decision to step down after the election defeat. ‚ÄúHe had virtually emerged as the main challenger to Modi in 2019 and should have continued to build the party. Why did he voluntarily withdraw from the scene?‚Äù Singh tweeted. Singh said those leaders opposed to Rahul‚Äôs aggressive politics should quit the party.



In Video: Congress Lok Sabha MPs demand Rahul Gandhi to take over as party chief

Title: Rush of PILs in SC over Dubey killing
Content:
Vikas Dubey was killed in an encounter when he allegedly tried to flee from police custody following a road ac... Read More

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court on Saturday saw a rush of PILs seeking court-monitored investigations into the encounter killing of gangster Vikas Dubey on Friday.

The first off the block was advocate Anoop Prakash Awasthi, who termed the encounter a ‚Äòcold-blooded killing‚Äô and referred to UP Police as an ‚Äúorganised gang of criminals‚Äù by quoting a half-century-old observation of Justice A N Mulla. He said Dubey‚Äôs killing appeared to be motivated to ‚Äúeliminate a crucial witness to the criminal-police-politician nexus in UP‚Äù.

‚ÄúAn exemplary action coupled with big reforms is needed to infuse public confidence in the cardinal principle ‚Äòmight is not right‚Äô and to assure them they are not living in a medieval draconian authoritative state but in a state governed by rule of law,‚Äù he said.

Awasthi sought CBI/NIA/court-monitored probe into the separate encounter killings of Dubey, his five associates as well as the 60 cases pending against him and his gang, which he said could throw light on the unholy criminal-police-politician nexus.

Meanwhile, NGO People‚Äôs Union for Civil Liberties has filed an application seeking an SIT probe into encounter killings of Dubey and aides Amar Dubey and Prabhat Mishra. It sought the application to be made part of its earlier PIL, which had sought probe into encounter killings in 2017-18 and a probe by a committee headed by a sitting SC-judge into the criminal-police-politician nexus.

The NGO said, ‚ÄúEncounter/administrative liquidation is a serious crime ‚Äî murder/culpable homicide, is an offence against the entire society. If such a crime is committed with the support of the state..., it takes a very serious dimension, questioning the entire rule of law and governance in accordance with the Constitution.‚Äù

Title: You can‚Äôt help anyone at the cost of your own mental health. Take care of yourself first
Content:
To help readers cope with their corona anxieties, The Times of India has launched Talk it Out, a series under which our panel of

will answer your

. This week‚Äôs advice comes from counselling psychologist

I‚Äôve had

for many years, but couldn‚Äôt identify it somehow. I come from a well-to-do family, but shifted to a middle class environment after marriage. I was pressured to settle down within a month, learn customs and language of the new state. I was expecting support since it was a love marriage; instead, I realised that I was brought here to be a maid. I felt as if I was locked in my own house struggling to breathe. It was worse after my first delivery due to postpartum depression. I have lived these years with cheating by my partner, helplessness and loneliness. The lockdowns have only worsened the situation. I need to hug my children and get that spark back in my relationship with my husband but I hate them all. Help.

‚Äî Anonymous

I am 49 and have been on medication for 31 years. My mother died when I was just 7. I am the only child and my father put pressure on me to study hard in school and college, and later forced me into marriage against my wishes. I don‚Äôt have a good relationship with my wife of 20 years. I love both my kids dearly, but my son, 15, gets annoyed with me often. I don‚Äôt want to be with my abusive wife anymore. I tell my father that he is responsible for my personal trauma. What should I do?

‚ÄîRavi Menaria

I am a 1st-year MSc student. My brother has had a mental health condition for four years. He breaks things at home when angry and leaves home when we scold him. Due to the lockdown, it has been difficult to get medical help for him. He has also stopped taking his medicines, saying that they make him feel sleepy and lethargic. I asked my parents to take him to a counsellor but our relatives scolded me for advising elders and have instead taken my brother to tantriks. Please help.

‚Äî Anonymous

I am a final-year physics student waiting for exams. For the last few days, I haven‚Äôt been feeling well emotionally. I have very few friends. I thought of sharing my feelings with them but it may needlessly trouble them. After my father passed away, it has been very difficult for me to stay calm and focused. I pretend to smile but deep down I want to scream my lungs out. On most days I feel really low. I have very few friends. Sometimes I feel I will never achieve anything in my life. I get scared seeing my mother‚Äôs unhappy face. I miss my papa. I am not able to talk about my feelings and anxiety to anyone. Please help me.

‚ÄîAnonymous

My son is 9. He is an intelligent boy with high interest in outdoor sports, but due to this pandemic and being confined to home, he is losing interest in studies, wants to play games on mobile phone all day or watch TV. He told me that he is getting frustrated and doesn't feel like doing anywhere or having any other hobby other than mobile games TV. How should I tackle this situation?

‚ÄîAnonymous

Want some advice?

Write to us at talkitout@timesgroup.com with your question, name and place. But if you wish to stay anonymous, do indicate that in your email.

I understand that you have been in a difficult situation for the past few years, and coping with depression and relationship issues. I really admire your courage for keeping a positive outlook in life despite such challenges. It will help if you can slowly try to bring about small changes within you, one day at a time. For example, start penning down your thoughts in a diary. Start by stating what you want and slowly create boundaries that will help you have your own space Speak to a therapist or a marriage counsellor. You could also reach out to your local women and child helpline or cell for emotional guidance.Sometimes parents forget that their children are born through them and not to them. I see that your father has made decisions in your life, sometimes even against your will. You made choices based on your circumstances. Have you talked to your wife? Think about relationship counselling and individual counselling. The past is over, and though your father made some decisions for you, your present and future are in your hands.Life can be very challenging for the family and caregivers of mental health patients. I understand that there is stigma attached to mental health and you are concerned about your brother. But you can‚Äôt help anyone at the cost of your own mental well-being. So, first take care of your own self. We live in a culture where people believe in unscientific practices. Respect their beliefs but put across your point of seeking professional help. You can start with approaching an online counsellor.I understand your grief. Waiting for exams and not having many friends to talk to can be challenging. I would recommend that you reflect on your life‚Äôs learnings and take time to heal. Speak to a friend, and if that‚Äôs not possible, speak to a professional counsellor as there are multiple emotions that need to be addressed. You can start working on what you want in your life professionally and personally. Think about past success and focus on your strengths. Pen down your thoughts in a diary.These are unprecedented times and extremely challenging for a lot of people. I can understand your worry about your son. I see that he was an active child before and as things have changed now he might be also finding it difficult to set himself in the new routine and a different lifestyle.I would recommend that you sit with your child and create a schedule. You can share your feelings about the routine challenges with him and ask him what he is feeling. Creating boundaries with a time-bound structure will help you both adjust to the new routine. You can enroll him for an online class like dance, karate, self-defense, etc. You can also do activities which involve physical movement like working out. The process of adjusting in the new lifestyle will take time, therefore I suggest you to be patient and regularly communicate with your child.

Title: It is the coronavirus that is killing the economy, not just the lockdown, says Prof Bhramar Mukherjee
Content:
The global fight against

has been as much about data as drugs and vaccines. In March, Bhramar Mukherjee, professor and Chair of Biostatistics at the University of Michigan School of Public Health, set up an interdisciplinary study team of 15 researchers from academic institutions in the US and India to work on Covid-19 modelling and predictions. The team updates their projections daily using their app covind19.org. Mukherjee, who grew up in Kolkata where her family still lives, tells Neelam Raaj how this was a way for quarantined data scientists to do their bit for their homeland

India recently overtook Russia to record the world‚Äôs third largest caseload but some experts point out that per capita caseload is low as well as the case fatality rate. What do you think of this assessment?

What do you think of the quality of Covid-19 data released by India?

When it comes to lockdowns, it‚Äôs been economists versus the public health experts. What is your stand?

Some models have predicted a peak in August with the worst getting over by October. What‚Äôs your take?

Data scientists have been playing an important role in this fight against coronavirus. What made you focus on India?

There has been a lot of discussion on how countries with women leaders have dealt better with the pandemic. Do you agree?

Success stories like Dharavi have hit the headlines. What are the lessons that other parts of the country can draw from India‚Äôs largest slum?

What is your reaction to the US homeland security service‚Äôs policy on F-1 students leaving the country because of the universities going online to offer public health protection to faculty, staff and students?

You‚Äôve tweeted that you‚Äôve been reading poetry in the pandemic. Can you quote some of your favourite lines that have kept you going?

The numbers are not a surprise as we had predicted that India will cross the million mark by mid-July back in May. I think the concept of per capita case-load being low as a metric of success is fundamentally flawed. We need to think about the number of ‚Äúactive cases‚Äù and expected hospitalisations in a metro/region and assess whether the healthcare capacity is able to handle serious cases. The case fatality rate does appear to be low for India (hovering around 3%), perhaps largely due to the younger population. However, if you calculate this rate based on the closed cases for whom you know the outcome definitively, this is higher (4.2%). I worry whether all deaths are being reported and whether the cause of death is being assigned appropriately.India is a very data-poor country when it comes to human health. We need granular level daily data on hospitalisation rates, death rates not just due to Covid-19, but related to severe acute respiratory infections (SARI) and influenza like illness (ILI) and overall. We need to be able to compare with historic trends to see the departure from those trends. We need demographics and mobility data at a finer geographical resolution. We need real-time sophisticated analyses that are automated. It is a pity since India has such wealth in statistics and information technology.This is a long and painful crisis. We are on a Schrodinger‚Äôs seesaw where, as policymakers, you change positions nimbly to maintain this balance between economic and public health costs and benefits. I do believe national lockdown was not sustainable beyond June, and now it is time to closely monitor the data and escalate prevention strategies, testing and alert health care systems. This is a nasty virus, we cannot let our guards down and simply surrender to destiny. The public needs to learn how to manage and minimise their own risks. You have to remember that even if lockdowns are not in place, the economy suffers like in Sweden which suffered economic shrinkage and reduction despite not imposing a lockdown. It is the virus that is killing the economy, not just the lockdown. We need to deal with the virus effectively and the economy will swing back up.I am sceptical about long-term projections from these forecasting models including our own as the ground reality changes rapidly. Look at Delhi. The reproduction number is around 0.8 for the past few days which shows excellent progress and that humans can beat dire projections. The concept of a national peak is nebulous and there will be a wave of peaks cascading through the nation over the next couple of months. Our current projections indicate 1.2-1.4 million cases by July 30 and high alert in eastern ( Bihar West Bengal ) and southern States ( Karnataka , Telangana, Andhra Pradesh).I started this project with the altruistic goal of bringing together Indian doctoral and post-doctoral students who are studying in the US, and in particular in my own department. I wanted to repurpose their anxiety and confinement into something meaningful. It is our service as quarantined data scientists to our motherland where most of our loved ones are.I have written a paper on this with my students. As the first woman chair of one of the world‚Äôs oldest, finest and largest Biostatistics departments, I was naturally intrigued by what the data said. We found that women leaders are ahead in all public health metrics but the difference is not quite statistically significant. I think it is not just women, but countries that are progressive enough to choose diverse leaders are doing better in fighting this disease. Perhaps this is something to think about as we choose our future leaders!This is not rocket science, we can do it, even in a low-resource setting where the odds are stacked against us. This gives us hope. We need centralised isolation and quarantine to prevent household and cluster transmission. Self-isolation and quarantine is not a solution in populous countries with large households and congested neighborhoods. We need grassroots level community health workers monitoring symptoms/temperature when large-scale testing is not possible. We need to protect health care workers with adequate PPE so they are not afraid to do the work. We need to lead with efficiency, empathy and elasticity, scale up things that are working, shut down policies that are failing.Several universities, including University of Michigan have joined forces and filed a lawsuit to seek temporary restraining order on this policy and bar ICE from enforcing the order. I am outraged by this policy which is against the fundamental values of the US education system. Senseless acts like this can harm US universities for a long time. Moreover, people are being forced to teach in person sacrificing public health safety. It is against science and law. My heart goes out to all F-1 students for the chaos, stress, anxiety and uncertainty they are facing right now. I hope this attempted promulgation by a cruel and reckless administration goes nowhere. If everybody who has ever held an F-1 visa in the US stops going to work for seven days, the system will collapse. I came to the US on an F-1 visa in 1996 and I am proud of my journey as an immigrant scholar in American academia.I have been thinking about the times when humanity underwent similar major global crisis like plague, world wars, famine and how artists expressed themselves during these bleak times. Three poets have really helped me through this quarantine time, WB Yeats, Emily Dickinson and Rainer Maria Rilke. ‚ÄúSecond Coming‚Äù by Yeats and ‚ÄúHope‚Äù by Dickinson has become my daily mantra.
